columns.text: In this exercise, we are asked to assess the alternative issue methods.

## 15.3a

The **right offer** is a public offering of shares in which existing shareholders are initially given securities. There is no additional stock issued in a rights issue, lowering a present company's ownership proportion as long as the existing shareholder exercises all of his rights to maintain an equal proportion shareholding by subscribing to new share financings at or below market rates. 

On the other hand, in a **cash offer**, the additional stock is offered to outside shareholders, diluting the existing ownership. This is a public offering of securities for cash sale to the public.

## 15.3b

The procedure of issuing shares of a private company to the market in the issuance of new stock is known as an **initial public offering (IPO)**. This enables a company to generate revenue from the general public.

The initial public offering is a cash offer since its stockholders would not have to sell their interests publicly for cash if they decided to acquire them.
